# Chapter 2. The Technique {background-color="#0f2027" .chapter-slide}
<h2 style="color:white; border-bottom: 2px solid #3182bd; display:inline-block;">Why Negative Binomial?</h2>

## Why Not Linear Regression?

<div class="glass-box">
We are predicting **Crime Counts** (0, 1, 2, 5...), not continuous prices.
</div>

::: {.columns}
::: {.column width="60%"}
### The Distribution Reality
* Most stops have **Zero** crime (Safe).
* Some stops have extreme **High** crime (Hotspots).
* **Variance >> Mean**: This "Overdispersion" breaks standard Poisson models.

### Our Method: Negative Binomial
* **Why?** It handles the "Long Tail" of crime data perfectly.
* **Offset:** We used `offset(log(Exposure_Days))` to mathematically account for the fact that weekdays occur more often than weekends.
:::

::: {.column width="40%"}
<div style="background: white; padding: 10px; border-radius: 10px;">
![](distribution_histogram.png)
</div>
<p style="font-size: 0.6em; text-align: center; color: #aaa;">Fig 1. The right-skewed distribution necessitates a Negative Binomial approach.</p>
:::
:::

---

## The Core Hypothesis: The Interaction

We tested a specific theory about crowd behavior:

<div class="glass-box" style="text-align: center; font-size: 1.5em; font-weight: bold; color: #fff;">
"Crowds behave differently on <span style="color:#de2d26">Weekends</span>."
</div>

<br>

::: {.columns}
::: {.column width="50%"}
### ğŸ¢ Weekday Crowds
* Commuters & Students
* Routine Patterns
* **"Eyes on the Street" (Guardianship)**
:::

::: {.column width="50%"}
### ğŸ‰ Weekend Crowds
* Nightlife & Leisure
* Unfamiliar Areas
* **"Targets" (Risk)**
:::
:::

<br>

$$Crime = \beta_0 + \beta_1(Ridership) + \beta_2(Weekend) + \beta_3(Ridership \times Weekend)$$

# Chapter 5. Critical Analysis {background-color="#0f2027" .chapter-slide}
<h2 style="color:white; border-bottom: 2px solid #aaa; display:inline-block;">Safety & Ethics</h2>

## Where Does The Model Fail? (Residuals)

::: {.columns}
::: {.column width="60%"}
<div style="background: white; padding: 5px; border-radius: 10px;">
![](residual_map.png)
</div>
:::

::: {.column width="40%"}
<div class="glass-box" style="margin-bottom: 20px;">
### <span class="highlight-red">Red Zones (Under-predicted)</span>
* Model says "Safe," Reality is "Dangerous."
* *Cause:* Unobserved variables (e.g., Gang territory).
* *Action:* Needs **Human Intelligence**.
</div>

<div class="glass-box">
### <span class="highlight-blue">Blue Zones (Over-predicted)</span>
* Model says "Dangerous," Reality is "Safe."
* *Risk:* Potential for **Over-policing** in minority neighborhoods.
* *Action:* Do not deploy without verification.
</div>
:::
:::

## Ethical Safeguards & Conclusion

<div class="glass-box" style="margin-bottom: 40px;">
### ğŸ›¡ï¸ Preventing Bias
1.  **Resource, Not Arrests:** Guide deployment of **Safety Ambassadors** & **Lighting (CPTED)**, not just armed officers.
2.  **Human-in-the-Loop:** High-risk flags must be validated by district captains.
3.  **Bias Auditing:** Explicitly controlled for Poverty/Demographics to avoid proxying crime for poverty.
</div>

<div style="text-align: center; font-size: 1.2em;">
**Safe Passage** moves SEPTA from reacting to crimes *after* they happen to preventing them *where* they are most likely to occur.
</div>
